key_work.title: Letters to Arralla
key_work.credit_line:
Key art, concept art & stills from Letters to Arralla

Little Pink Clouds, Australia, 2024

Courtesy Little Pink Clouds
key_work.brief_description:
Letters to Arralla takes players to a whimsical island with pink skies, rolling hills and fruit n’ veggie villagers. As a mail delivery-turnip, players can explore the island, help neighbours and snoop into their business by reading their mail.

Letters to Arralla presents a cheeky dreamworld inspired by wistful memories of childhood imagination. Its charming playscape and soft plush characters cherish an idyllic form of traditional ‘adorable’ femininity. ‘Cosy’ and ‘wholesome’ indie games have flourished in recent years. They offer a refreshing take on videogame conventions and appeal to players who don’t want violence and competition and instead value gentle interactions and positive game worlds. This game reproduces the soft, warm textures reminiscent of the comfort of a beloved stuffed toy.

Letters to Arralla is currently under development and is supported by VicScreen.

end.title: Amélie
end.creator_credit: Jean-Pierre Jeunet, Madeline Fontaine, Hervé Schneid, Arne Meerkamp van Embden, Claudie Ossard, France 3 Cinéma, MMC Independent, Tapioca Films, UGC, Victoires Productions, Aline Bonetto and Guillaume Laurant
end.brief_description: At a tiny Parisian café, the adorable yet painfully shy Amélie accidentally discovers a gift for helping others. Soon Amelie is spending her days as a matchmaker, guardian angel, and all-around do-gooder. But when she bumps into a handsome stranger, will she find the courage to become the star of her very own love story?

constellations_other.name: Cosy correspondences
constellations_other.description: From anonymous love letters, pen-pals and magical deliveries, explore connections between films, TV series and videogames where sending letters and messages are at the heart of the story.

links.description: Both protagonists in Letters to Arralla and Amelie turn to the morally ambiguous side of the postal service, reading other people’s mail or forging mail, for a positive purpose: helping people in their community.

start.title: Il Mare
start.creator_credit: Lee Hyun-seung, Lee Eun-su, Lee Min-su, Blue Cinema, Dream Venture Capital, Sidus, UniKorea Pictures, Kim Ki-chul, Kim Eun-jeong, Yeoh Gee-na, Kim Mi-yeong and Won Tae-yeon
start.brief_description: In the year 1999, a young woman leaves her quaint seaside house and returns to the city, leaving in the mailbox a card for the next owner, with instructions to forward any mail of hers to the new address. In the year 1997, a jaded young architect moves into the same house and finds the letter. His reply, which he slips into the mailbox, finds its way to her, beginning a parallel-time love story separated by a span of two years.

end.creator_credit: Eiko Tanaka, Hayao Miyazaki, Toshio Suzuki, Nippon Television Network Corporation and Tokuma Shoten
end.brief_description: A young witch, on her mandatory year of independent life, finds fitting into a new community difficult while she supports herself by running an air courier service.

constellations_other.name: Cosy correspondences
constellations_other.description: From anonymous love letters, pen-pals and magical deliveries, explore connections between films, TV series and videogames where sending letters and messages are at the heart of the story.

links.description: Kiki relies on her magic to fly and deliver mail in Kiki’s Delivery Service. Magic similarly facilitates mail delivery in Il Mare, as magic mailbox allows the two protagonists to communicate across time.

start.title: Mary and Max
start.brief_description: A tale of friendship between two unlikely pen pals: Mary, a lonely, eight-year-old girl living in the suburbs of Melbourne, and Max, a forty-four-year old, severely obese man living in New York, for which Adam Elliot won an Academy Award.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

constellations_other.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

links.description: The title characters in Mary and Max live on opposite sides of the world and form a decades-long friendship solely through letter writing. Similarly, Kathleen and Joe in You’ve Got Mail meet and deepen their relationship through anonymous email correspondence.
